head.title: Part of a Park Is Renamed To Honor Courage of the Irish

hedline.hl1: Part of a Park Is Renamed To Honor Courage of the Irish

abstract.p: Northwestern part of V E Macy Park in Irvington, NY, is renamed Great Hunger Memorial Park, commemorating suffering and courage of Irish during potato famine (S)

block.p: The northwestern part of V.E. Macy Park in Irvington was renamed the Great Hunger Memorial Park in a dedication ceremony on Wednesday. The renaming brought to a close a sometimes bumpy 10-year-long effort in Westchester County to commemorate the suffering and courage of the Irish people during the potato famine of the mid-19th century. Among the dignitaries at the dedication was Eugene Hutchinson, Ireland's consul general to the United States. The Great Hunger Memorial of Westchester County is a stone-and-bronze sculpture, created by the Irish artist Eamonn O'Doherty, that depicts a family walking away from symbols of the past toward an unknowable future.
